review_text: No doubt, the view is fantastic and the yurt itself is super cool- I would stay again. The sunsets were phenomenal, and you can hear the cayotes calling to each other at dusk. The road to get to the yurt, took about 35 minutes from the paved road on a rocky dusty path but we were able to make trip in a Rav4 just fine. The port-a-potty was clean and not far from the yurt. The shower, that is offered is 500+ steps from the yurt though the trees and sagebrush, and as described, is outside the host's main house attached to their porch. We got to see a peacock roaming while showering. If you are a camper--you will LOVE the experience. If you have never camped, you may be put-off. Elko also has a bunch of Mormon Crickets- which are harmless but UGLY and chirpy. Shannon and Rob were responsive when we had difficulty locating the shower and when the Goal Zero device (run via solar panels) got to 40% and had to be switched to generator as it runs the fridge.

review_text: Great place! The unpaved road in a downpour was interesting, but we made it with no problem. It’s further than you think. Also, the directions don’t mention the gate you need to open and close at the entrance to the driveway of the yurt. Very clean. No running water and you have to conserve electricity since it’s all solar, but we were in the middle of a fantastic lighting and thunder storm and it was fun to just sit and watch. A bathroom is being added, so there is only an outhouse, which can be a little unnerving to use at 3:00 in the morning. There isn’t a mirror, but maybe that’s a good thing. 😂. There were towels, but we didn’t see any wash cloths or hand towels. The WiFi worked great. The oversized “bean bag” was extremely comfortable—the bed not so much. We brought cards, games and food to cook. Great communication. Awesome view. Definitely recommend!

The home was surrounded by beautiful snow-covered mountains with a lake down the road. It was a bit windy some of the days, but that’s to be expected during the winter. My daughter loved playing outside in the snow. We had everything we needed to feel at home. The kitchen was well equipped with cookware and utensils, so we were able to cook and make Christmas dinner during our stay. If you like to drink hot tea or cocoa, I do recommend bringing your own tea kettle, as there isn’t one in the home; however, we did just fine without one and were able to boil water in a mug using the microwave. The dining room had enough seating for all 6 of us to eat together. The living room had cozy recliners and a sofa, where we watched TV together and connected to our Netflix account. The water stayed nice and hot throughout the home. The decor inside the home was very cute as well, with a lot of little bird houses. If you choose to wash laundry, it does take a while to dry (3 cycles of drying per load). Make sure you wash in small loads. Amber provided laundry soap and plenty of clean towels for our stay. I had a really great time. If I had any questions or needed anything during my stay, Amber always responded quickly and made sure to send her Housekeeper. I definitely recommend you check out this gem! You won’t regret it. I would love to stay again, in the future, during the spring or summer months, so I can make use of the lake and better use of the hot tub. Thank you for hosting us! My family and I will cherish the memories we made forever.

The “apartment” is small, but suited our needs. The bed was comfortable, the shower warm, and the TV and wifi worked well. There is a microwave and a coffee maker provided too. There is a small outdoor seating area with a lovely view of the Ruby Mountains. Currently there is not a fenced area for your dog, but Jeanne assured us that she was working on resolving that situation. In fact there was a workman there during our stay fixing some of the fencing.
Overall, I would certainly recommend staying with Jeanne if you want a quieter, more rural setting which we certainly did.
